title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.9.33 | 01-05-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Om Agyana Timiraandhasya Gyananjanishalakaya Chakshurunmilitam Yena Tasmait Shri Gurave Namaha
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers, invoking blessings and paying respects to the spiritual master and Lord Krishna.

segments.key_quote: Shri Krishna is the intimate friend of Arjuna. He has appeared on this earth in his transcendental body, which resembles the bluish color of the tamala tree.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the verse from Srimad Bhagavatam (1.9.33), explaining that it is Bhishma's prayer to Krishna as he is leaving his body, focusing on the beauty and attractiveness of Krishna's transcendental form.

segments.key_quote: Krishna has got three kinds of energies... internal potency, his external potency and his marginal potency.
segments.summary: The speaker explains Srila Prabhupada's purport, elaborating on Krishna's three energies: internal (spiritual), external (material), and marginal (living beings), and their respective functions and influences.

segments.key_quote: Krishna never comes in contact with the illusory energy or the material energy.
segments.summary: The speaker continues to explain how Krishna uses his internal potency when he appears in the material world and how the illusory energy affects conditioned souls but not Krishna or his pure devotees, and how Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva act as directors of the material energy under Krishna's will.

segments.key_quote: When Krishna comes to this material world, it is said here, he comes by his internal potency... he appears in his transcendental form.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes that Krishna appears in his transcendental form, untouched by material energy, and that his form is uniquely attractive, surpassing any beauty found in the material universe.

segments.key_quote: Arjuna was always a conqueror because the Lord was his friend.
segments.summary: The speaker explains Arjuna's position as a conqueror due to his friendship with Krishna, and why Bhishma addresses Krishna as 'Vijaya Sakhe' (friend of Arjuna), highlighting Krishna's pleasure in being associated with his devotees and the different transcendental humors (Rasas) in their relationships.

segments.key_quote: Devotees are simply by remembering Krishna's beautiful form... able to completely situate themselves on the transcendental platform and they are never touched by the material energy.
segments.summary: The speaker lists the five spiritual Rasas and explains how devotees can elevate themselves to the transcendental platform by remembering Krishna's form, name, activities, and qualities, thus remaining untouched by material energy.

segments.key_quote: A particular devotee's own relationship with Krishna is relished by the devotee to the highest degree.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by emphasizing that each devotee relishes their specific relationship (Rasa) with Krishna to the highest degree, using Bhishma's chivalrous humor (Virya Rasa) and Radharani's Madhuriya Rasa as examples.
